BE11:09am

The Bank of England may have to cut interest rates even if the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, a senior official at the central bank said on Friday as European Commission data showed further weakness in the economy. 

“In such a scenario — not a no-deal Brexit, but persistently high uncertainty — it probably will be appropriate to maintain an expansionary monetary policy stance and perhaps to loosen further,” Michael Saunders, a member of the rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee, said in a speech in Barnsley, northern England. 

“I think it is quite plausible that the next move in [the] bank rate would be down rather than up.”

Irish HF guy @BE, IP group seems happy to be out from under WoodFord stable. Same thing happened to Malin in Ireland, he placed most of his holding at €3.10 and the shares rallied to €3.70 €3.80
nightingale20201 morning all
Tom Dalgleish Gina Rinehart is a shareholder in Sirius and she has clout
BE11:12am

GBP has outperformed month-to-date within G10, but our outlook is consistent with weaker levels. The
outperformance had come about amid reduced odds of a “no deal” (and some optimism on a deal occurring) by the end of October, which still elicited a market response given crowded investor shorts. As a result, GBP valuations are not cheap any longer, having strengthened by 3% in TWI terms since mid-August—on a REER basis, SEK and CAD screen cheaper than GBP (exhibit 1). However, our base case as outlined by J.P. Morgan economists is less optimistic, specifically that (a) the odds of a deal by 31st October are very low given the lack of alternative arrangements to the Irish backstop that would be acceptable to the EU and a compressed timeframe, and (b) beyond that, the odds of hard Brexit/ no deal around the January deadline have actually increased given recent polls that indicate that the lead of Tories vs. Labour has been relatively stable despite recent events and still suggest on margin a Conservative majority in the elections

Irish HF guy @BBBC, Metro bank seems to be on a Thomas Cook course for oblivion
Greedy_When_Others_Are_Fearful @BBBC you know how to pick them!
BE11:13am

The recent Supreme Court ruling raises some uncertainties but doesn’t alter the expected outcome as outlined above. The expectation has been for the political pressure on Boris Johnson to increase as a result and his resignation as PM and Tory Party leader can’t be ruled out. However, the latter in particular or a change in the hard Brexit stance is highly unlikely given that the polls haven’t reacted much thus far. On the other side, recent comments from the EU have increasingly indicated that the odds of a deal by the end of October are unlikely with Barnier stating overnight that the EU was still waiting for “workable ideas” from the UK.

Bulletin Board Bag Carrier @Irish HF guy - on a slippery slope for sure
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Brexit risks rather than the BoE stance has been the dominant driver of GBP in our view, but even BoE is turning more dovish. Our approach has been to downplay BoE hawkishness (without a change in the Brexit outlook) as a source of support for GBP, but we have viewed a dovish signal as more relevant for FX markets. Comments from BoE’s Saunders who usually has hawkish leanings indicated this morning that a more dovish stance is indeed evolving with the BoE potentially easing given ongoing Brexit uncertainty. In addition, the PMIs next week are not expected to send an encouraging signal either.

Greedy_When_Others_Are_Fearful @BBBC are you long Boris too?
Tom Dalgleish Rinehart was born Hancock, lineage to Cornwall tin mines although her father was a pastoralist with a spotter plane
BE11:14am

Against this backdrop—not-so-cheap valuations, ongoing political uncertainty with risks of “no deal” still lingering and a more dovish BoE—we view risks to GBP tilted to the downside as well in the near-term and recommend re-selling GBP vs. CHF outright. The immediate catalysts to watch are the Conservative Party conference over the weekend which clearly takes on additional significance as it will shed more light on possible UK proposals. But we doubt that there will be any additional substance to imply a breakthrough. Upcoming polls will be important to track as well as they will indicate if the recent dramatic turn of events has affected the support for Tories.

Carnival PLC (CCL:LSE): Last: 3,301, down 88 (-2.60%), High: 3,393, Low: 3,293, Volume: 268.82k
Tom Dalgleish They can just hold the leases
marktime In a tube. Like a moving walkway from Paddington to Heathrow, and back

Always an oddity in the British reporting calendar due to its UK listing being somewhere between an afterthought and an irrelevance.

Tom Dalgleish and Gina wanted to square off with Fairfax but was stymied
BE11:24am

Anyway. Weaker outlook, fuel costs up.

BE11:24am

UBS can summarise the headlines.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

We are downgrading CCL to Neutral from Buy, with a price target of £36, down from £47 previously, as we lower our 2020 estimates on a lower valuation multiple given a more muted earnings growth outlook due to further weakening in European sourcing and 2 years of flat EPS. Our EPS is now at $4.26 for 2020e, down from $4.80 previously, as we lower constant currency yield to up 50bps, down from +1% previously. Our valuation multiple goes to the lower end of 11-12x, down from 13-14x previously, which is where CCL has traded in more muted growth environments. While CCL is currently trading below historical valuation multiples, we see no clear catalyst for upside near-term given lack of earnings growth. Currently the stock is trading at around 10x EPS vs. 3-, 5- and 10-yr average of 14-15x, but EPS is likely to show no growth in 2019 or 2020. While we believe CCL remains a well-managed company with strong brands and growth in the longer term, external forces have impacted and are likely to continue to impact CCL’s near term earnings outlook.

BE11:25am

Bookings for 1H'20 are ahead in load at prices in line, though bookings taken since June are down in volume and price. So will that rate of decline move yields in 1H into negative territory? Overall, yield comps will be easier in 2H, with the comp base of +0.6% in 1H'19 and -1.3% in 2H'19, so negative yield in 1H'20 won't preclude growth in 2H

BE11:26am

With over 50% of sourcing from North America, we still expect yield growth in those regions, and slightly less growth in UK but still positive yields given their comp to this year's close-in disruption. We expect further declines in yield from Costa and to a lesser extent, from AIDA. And continued yield growth in Asia and Australia/NZ. Weighting those expectations to CCL's sourcing, and including the 50 bps of negative mix impact, we are reducing our 2020 yield estimate to +0.5% from +1%.

SkippyGoLucky Morning All
marktime Not sure Trump would tick the corp governance box hunting down whistleblowers as spies
den With regards to Metro Bank - the rent they pay on their branches must be a big problem for them (amongst other things!)
11:26 am
BE11:27am

And Berenberg to do the "told you so" thing.

BE11:27am

When we downgraded Carnival on 28 June 2019 ... we saw a fine balance between the macro risks and the company’s optically cheap valuation. The Q319 results have heightened our fears, and with the shares down by just 2% from when we downgraded, we believe the time is right to take the shares to Sell. When we factor in a modest decline in our 2020 net yields, which were already well below consensus, and the greater-than-expected increase in fuel costs, our 2020E EPS falls to $4.00. We lower our price target for Carnival Corporation to $38 (and to £31 for Carnival plc).

BE11:27am

While Carnival has confirmed that bookings for
2020 are running ahead of this year at flat prices, it has attested that since June, bookings are lower both in terms of number of bookings and price. Although the company has flagged the tough macro conditions in Europe and Asia, our analysis in our June 2019 note concluded that Carnival was also seeing pressure in its US domestic market. We remain of this view and with the US home furnishings index continuing to weaken, an indicator that we have previously argued is a lead indicator on cruise yields, we believe that our analysis is being validated. We take our net yields down by 1% in 2020.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Carnival has to date been the most optimistic of its peer group on its scrubber implementation programme, helping offset the implications of IMO2020. This was reflected in consensus and in our numbers; however, in the Q319 release, the company has indicated that 40% of its 2020 fuel usage will be MGO. This means that Carnival expects fuel costs of $1.8bn, which is $200m (or $0.30 of EPS) worse than we expected or current consensus.

BE11:29am

In combination, the weaker operational outlook and
the higher fuel costs result in our EPS estimates for 2020 coming down to $4, an 11% decrease, with a similar double-digit increase in 2021.

BE11:29am

In terms of our price target, we use a blend of multiples and DCF, then layer in our increased fears of a deterioration in the economic environment. This causes our price target for Carnival Corporation to fall from $48 to $38 per share. While at 9.5x 2020F P/E multiple it is a material discount to the long-run average, our concerns about earnings and the risk from a flagging booking environment justify our decision. We take our recommendation to Sell from Hold.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

It's a while since I've read anything about labour on cruise ships.

Tom Dalgleish @MT, impeachment would not happen until after the election so it's a smart gambit
BE11:31am

BE11:31am

[V]ery importantly, we think the BoE will show forbearance ahead of the Jan-20 intermediary MREL deadline. This is a rather “soft” deadline and we highlight regulatory forbearance when Coop Bank breached Pillar 2A – a more “stringent” concept – back in early 2017. In addition, it is worth highlighting that the NPS base prospectus sheds some light on Metro’s deposit situation, and it is clear that this has stabilized during the summer.

BE11:35am

Their argument is that, once the Thomas Cook stoosh has blown over, Metro will come back.

BE11:35am

But at a smaller size.

Soundbuy Go Compare - AutoSave business ........more than 220,000 customers
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Metro’s MREL needs are relatively modest and we expect forbearance from the regulator allowing them to issue these instruments over a longer time period, should this be necessary

Soundbuy ...........basically beating their own guidance............
Irish HF guy :soundbuy, would you believe they have an investment in an entity called weflip.. I wonder did Adam N allow them have the "we" in the name lol
BE11:36am

So -- a stay of execution. But it's still Metro, so .....

BE11:37am

Notwithstanding our expectation for a short-term rebound of Mtroln 5 ½ £23-28, our Underweight recommendation on Metro Bank is a reflection of structural challenges. In particular, we flag the following risks: firstly, despite the recent stabilisation and reversal in outflows, ongoing pressure in the stock price and negative press coverage could have a negative impact on deposits going forward. Secondly, ongoing and new investigations are a veryrelevant risk. Thirdly, and at the risk of saying the obvious, issuing NPS at ~7.5% is not sustainable for a bank with a weak profitability profile. Lastly, the bank has a higher exposure to those segments that are likely to be most impacted from an adverse Brexit outcome (e.g. interest-only residential and BTL mortgages; a very large foot print to London and South-East England).

Soundbuy Aye .......Look After My Bills and weflip
11:37 am
BE11:37am

All of which looks reasonable to me. It's not the BoE's job to push banks over the cliff, but it isn't the BoE's job to stop them going over of their own accord.

undefined
marktime Well if the rumours of an urgent mini budget are true we will find out soon, but my guess is more spending on services and tax cuts to woo voters and inward investors
Irish HF guy GoCo group, £400m EV for a business which generated £8m in cash in the 6m to June 2019. I would say richly valued.
BE11:39am

(@Irish: tickers only annoy me when I don't know what the hell they are. Incorrect names are fine. British Airways, WeWork, Google, Yule Catto, whatever.)

11:39 am
BE11:40am

With regards GoCompare's Autosave stuff yesterday ....

BE11:40am

GOCO reports that Autosave (Automated Energy Switching) has surpassed 220k customers +28% on the July figure and ahead of the group's year-end target to grow customers by at least 25%. It raises its year-end target to 260k against the 175k reported in July following the acquisition of Look After My Bills. LAMB, which management praised for its on-line marketing capabilities seems to be leading to a welcome pick-up in momentum given the groups aspirations to have 3m customers by FY22. We make no change to our forecast £9.5m trading loss from this division in the current year, assuming that much of the growth will be reinvested to meet this target. It does however give us some comfort that our forecast break-even in FY21, at c 500k customers is within sights. At this early stage we include 10p in our target price for automated switching. If management can deliver to its 3m target, this would increase to 60p.

BE11:40am

That's Stifel.

SkippyGoLucky @Irish HF guy - thanks for the heads up!
marktime Wasn't Yule Catto the guy in the fridge attacking Clouseau
11:40 am
BE11:41am

And this is Peel Hunt.

BE11:41am

GoCo announced today that since 8 July, the number of
customers of AutoSave has increased by c28% to more than 220,000 live customers. This surpasses previous guidance of 25% growth by the end of the year. The better than expected customer numbers has demonstrated that there is a strong appetite for automated switching services. Management now expects to achieve 260,000 (50% increase) customers by the year end. The additional growth will be delivered within the previous guided marketing spend.
While we are not changing our current forecasts today, the faster growth in customer numbers gives us confidence that the company is in a solid position to achieve market expectations for 2020. GoCo is currently trading on a discount to its peers on NTM PER of 12.7x. We maintain our Buy.

Blank canvas anything on Persimmon? Up 4% despite the Brexit madness

Soundbuy Jefferies upgrade..........

undefined
BE11:43am

Persimmon! I'm glad you asked.

Soundbuy PT up a couple of quid.........
11:43 am
Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,151, up 84 (+4.06%), High: 2,157, Low: 2,081, Volume: 467.38k
Soundbuy That's Persimmon above........
BE11:43am

Jefferies has added up the obscene amount of money Persimmon can throw off from its landbank purchases.

Blank canvas Thanks Soundbuy
BE11:44am

Onto which it can eke out a housing scheme every other year at margins that'd shame a US drug company.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

The figures are, as ever with housebuilders, scandalous.

Are we there yet Persimmon - but a Labour government?
BE11:45am

Persimmon reports its landbank (based on current estimates of build cost including the newer levels of customer care and current house prices) has a gross margin (housing) of c.34%, close to 6.5ppt ahead of the top of the rest of the sector. This higher margin, we believe, arises from its meaningful conversion of strategic land 2014-17 and in particular the larger proportion of strategic land which was freehold (which can generate gross margins closer to 40%, rather than the c.23%-28% intake margin of peers). This advantage we see as sustainable with 1/3 of its 15,950 acres of strategic land (implying 8-10 years of land depending on density) reported to be held freehold, including the majority of the 18,000 plots in its landbank which are currently at planning allocation.

Soundbuy They downgrade Barratt though.........about 40p shaved off PT
BE11:47am

Ignore the untold damage caused by the deliberate perpetuation of a dysfunctional housing market, wallow in the cash.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

With a dividend yield of 11.1% (top 5 FTSE350), and a PE of 8x, Persimmon looks cheap against sector peers, but also the FTSE as a whole. While the additional cash outs for tax for UK corporates and the lumpy nature of land creditor payments imply FCF dips in 2020 (FCF yield 9.6%), the strong cash position on the balance sheet, we believe, should drive confidence in these payouts being made (JEFe forecast £870m-1bn of net cash for Persimmon 2019-21). We calculate that on a 5 years basis, Persimmon can return over half its market cap, with scope further from the return of 'surplus cash'. While we recognise the political sensitivity of returning cash to shareholders, and as such any step up in returns of cash to shareholders may come through share buybacks rather than higher dividends, this capital return remains difficult to ignore.

Blank canvas madre de dios!!!
BE11:47am

There's also some stuff in there about their houses being bad, the gist of which is that they'll get better.

BE11:48am

There was a sector note too. Hold on.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

gainst a sector that is +20% YTD, individual stock prices have seen a wide variation in performance largely dominated by investor perception of risk. With sector valuations appearing to reflect a c12% decline in house prices, we continue to believe risk from Brexit may be overplayed, offering value opportunities in the sector.

BE11:49am

As we move towards FY20 we see the FTSE leading dividend yields as the key attraction of the sector. However, with a dip in FCF expected next year across the sector (and dividend coverage not complete) we believe investors will return to focus on the stronger balance sheet (as an underpin to dividend, but also offering scope for additional returns/share buybacks). Key pick: Persimmon. Scope for additional longer-term returns: Watkin Jones, Countryside, Berkeley, McCarthy & Stone.

BE11:49am

Watkin Jones does student digs and build to rent investments, right?

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Both marked as having downside protection in case consumers stop wanting to live in houses.

BE11:50am

Otherwise, buy landbank. All that tasty, unused landbank.

BE11:50am

Consensus forecasts appear to assume that, while build cost inflation appears to be moderating, it will continue to nibble away at margins. Cost savings and efficiencies from new housing ranges can provide some offset. However, we see the gross margin on land banks as the best guide to profitability (reflective of all these factors, and including the balance of previous margin gain from historical house price inflation). We believe investors should focus where there is upside in consensus towards these land bank margins. Key pick: Persimmon.

Ulster Pension Fund Housebuilders are surely not a buy, if the UK govt does actually pull off a hard Brexit then they will go down and if for some reason a deal is done and an agreement reached, then BoE would start raising rates and therefore send housebuilders down
Ulster Pension Fund Yield aside....
GBKrona @soundbuy - if you have the DPL note please would you put it in the usual place?
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Was it us who once described housebuilders as landbank hedge funds? Ones that are actively discouraged to build houses because to do so is to crystalise the value of their key appreciating asset?

Soundbuy Watkin Jones - don't they have their own plane/jet?
BE11:52am

Which is the only possible reason they all trade at premiums to their book value?

Soundbuy No notes here I'm afarid.............BE's your man
BE11:52am

That certainly sounds like us. Bloody DPL

11:52 am
undefined

GBKrona Prudential plc pls?
BE11:54am

The Osram war continues.

Tom Dalgleish @Ulster, read again BE's first cut and paste today
11:56 am
BE11:56am

AMS bumps even before Bain bumps, now with the help of Advent after .. Carlyle, was it? ....... walked.

BE11:56am

You have to stop and remind yourself this is for Osram.

Soundbuy Osram war - there's light at the end of the tunnel
BE11:57am

Which was generally seen as a pretty substandard asset until this Punch & Judy thing kicked off.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Neil Campling of Mirabaud says "sell AMS, they've lost the nut."

BE11:58am

(I paraphrase.)

BE11:58am

Ams is paying a huge price on an assumption they can turn OSRAM around, integrate and manage the different cultures, issue huge amount of equity, end up with a highly levered business with very optimistic (likely unachievable) synergy targets when their own execution has been mixed at best. They are also taking on all the extra auto exposure which is a market that has no visibility, remains front and centre from both geopolitical risk and the increasing chance of global recession. So this deal is an enormous bet.

And why were Ams so late to this particular party? After all, Osram has been in play for 10 months. Something doesn’t stack up. The Deal is so big it suggests they are scared about current portfolio of products. ams try to say electronics portfolio is best in class, complete, and end to end solutions. Truth is these solutions commoditised and pricing risks from new competitors. And if you think where the current iPhone volumes are - the interest is in low end of the mix- Ams will get less $ per product at low end. And also, as Apple negotiate and try to offset lower product margin mix (eg remember China iPhone price is only 11% premium to US pricing, last year this was 30%} they will squeeze supplier pricing.

Ulster Pension Fund @Tom D, let the buybacks commence!
11:59 am
undefined
marktime But Persimmon have been buidling sh't houses to get the margin up, overpaying execs and and until recently ignoring furious buyers. Where is the backlash?

Just a quick line on Pru since it's requested.

Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,480, up 38 (+2.64%), High: 1,482, Low: 1,447, Volume: 1.26m
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Merrill pushing.

BE12:00pm

The demerger of Pru's UK and International businesses should complete on 21 October. The shares continue to look v cheap. Details on capital management, dividend and central costs look in line. Asian trading and US capital updates are of interest. Post demerger there is much to do. The next 12 months will be a critical period for the company in our view. Reiterate Buy.
